body: A 31-year-old man fatally stabbed his mother and critically wounded his father in their Brooklyn home on Monday morning, then jumped into the path of an oncoming subway train, the police said. The suspect, Ryan Devaney, was struck by a G train, the police said, but he is expected to live. The episode shook those who knew the family, who lived in a
title: Man Stabbed His Parents, Then Jumped in Front of a Train, the Police Say

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Center for Jewish History Through May 1, ''Zero to 10: First Decades/New Centuries,'' an exhibition in celebration of the center's 10th anniversary, featuring rare and historic items: a letter by Thomas Jefferson denouncing anti-Semitism and advocating religious freedom; a handwritten draft of Emma Lazarus's poem ''The
title: Spare Times

body: MY GREAT-GRANDMOTHER ANNA Arbeit was born in Brownsville, Brooklyn, in 1905. It was a rich area, she said. Pennsylvania Avenue was a doctors' row, and the doctor made house calls in a horse and buggy. Anna's parents came from Austria as teenagers, and their neighborhood was filled with Jews from all over Europe who spoke to each other in Yiddish.
title: One Borough, Five Generations

author: e-mail: realprop@nytimes.com
body: $13.05 MILLION 31 Ocean Parkway (at East 8th Street) Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn An investor has bought this 90,900-square-foot six-story 1929 elevator building with 85 rent-stabilized apartments -- 2 one-bedrooms, 55 three-bedrooms, 27 four-bedrooms and 1 five-bedroom. Buyer: Ocean 31 Limited Partnership Seller: Vested Property Brokers: Devin Cohen
title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Sale

body: If any heroes have emerged in the bedbug epidemic sweeping households, movie theaters, retailers, schools, offices, you-name-it nationwide, it is surely bedbug-sniffing dogs. Cute, diligent and armed with highly sophisticated detection tools -- their noses -- these dogs are fast becoming the American equivalent of the St. Bernard rescuing the
title: As the Dogs Sniff for Bedbugs, Some Homeowners Smell a Rat

body: AS a born-and-bred Manhattanite, Kirsten Abrams never considered living in any other borough. She and her partner, Jane Bishop, who is from Long Island, lived for the last four years at Le Rivage, an Art Deco rental building on West Street, just north of Battery Park. They paid $2,500 a month. When they moved there from the Upper East Side, the
title: THE HUNT; Building to Buyers: 'Here I Am'

body: Everybody has a dark side, and the Miser can think of no better time than Halloween weekend to help you explore it. Live music, dancing, absinthe and the dark arts are on the agenda at a Masquerade Macabre at a Brooklyn loft on Saturday. You must R.S.V.P. for the exact location (geminiandscorpio.com/events.html), and appropriate attire -- think
title: Weekend Miser

title: ON THE MARKET

author: Susannah Meadows, a former Newsweek correspondent who is spending the month running campaign coverage on newsweek.com, lives in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn.
body: When you're outnumbered, you learn to up your game - fast. I had twins almost three years ago and decided to stay home with them. I needed to play zone defense if I was ever going to get out of the house. When we first went to the playground, it felt like a round of pinball with multiple balls boinging everywhere. Then I figured out I could keep a
title: CITY ROOM; COMPLAINT BOX | TWIN DISCRIMINATION; 2 Boys + 1 Pedagogical Rule = 1 Displeased Mom

body: Two weeks ago Reverend Billy, the performance artist and activist best known as the leader of the Church of Stop Shopping, was plying his trade, public proselytizing. He and 15 members of the church's choir traveled from New York to Washington to stage a protest as part of Appalachia Rising, a campaign to end mountaintop-removal coal mining. They
title: Reverend Billy's Revelation: A Role for Money

body: THREE years ago, when Lisa Rosenberg and Thomas Kitts met at a neighborhood bar, they lived half a mile apart in Brooklyn, each renting a three-bedroom apartment, each divorced and the parent of two teenagers, each paying around $2,000 a month. They shared a love of music. One thing led to another and, ''knowing we would be together for the long
title: THE HUNT; A Tall Order for a Large Family

body: The doorways inside 30 Ocean Parkway, an Art Deco building in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, are studded with mezuzas of all sizes and styles: plastic, pewter, simple, gaudy, elegant. The people behind those doors are an assortment, too: Catholics, Baptists, Episcopalians, Buddhists, atheists and even a few observing the High Holy Days this week. ''I
title: On Doorways, A Jewish Custom Inherited by Gentiles

body: AS a child of the 1970s, I spent a number of birthday parties in striped tube socks and bright white roller skates, whizzing around a place called Skate Country in New Orleans. I loved the freedom of doing figure eights to Olivia Newton John or couples skating to the Bee Gees. But when I entered the Hunter College gym this spring for the Gotham
title: Aggression on Wheels, With Bruises as Badges

title: ON THE MARKET

body: WINDSOR TERRACE TOWN HOUSE $1,425,000 BROOKLYN: 20 Fuller Place A three-level 1915 brick house with two bedrooms, two and a half baths, a living room, a kitchen and a dining room on the top two floors. A windowed lower level has a living room, a bath and a laundry room. Patrick Brennan, Corcoran Group (917) 494-3307; www.corcoran.com, Open house
title: ON THE MARKET

body: THERE was probably little doubt that Matthew Galkin would someday find his way to New York. Even when he was a teenager in Highland Park, Ill., his classroom work suggested that a more willing audience might be found in the big city than in the upscale suburbs north of Chicago. ''When Matthew was in high school, his mother and I got a call from his
title: It Runs In the Family

body: Citing problems with electrical equipment, Consolidated Edison announced on Monday that it had decreased voltage to parts of Brooklyn by 8 percent and asked customers there and in part of the Upper West Side of Manhattan not to use ''nonessential'' electrical appliances, including air-conditioners, until the problems were corrected. The utility
title: Con Ed Reports Power Problems in City

body: To get to the city pool in Brooklyn's Gowanus neighborhood in the 1970s, a swimmer ran a gantlet. The pool sat amid factories and workshops, the streets around it crowded with trucks. Sex workers met clients near the gates, on Douglass Street. Still, clutching towels, local residents in need of a dip knew where to go, a block from the noxious
title: CITY ROOM; A Reprieve For an Oasis In Brooklyn With an Edge

title: ON THE MARKET

body: Annie and Ella Glazer, 6-year-old twins at Midtown West Elementary School in Manhattan, will be playing hooky with parental consent on Monday. In a pattern being repeated across New York City, their mother decided that the girls' last day of school would be on Friday -- even though, due to a quirk of the calendar, all students are supposed to
title: For Some Students, No More Pencils and No More Books Came a Day Early

body: THERE was a time, more than a century ago, when a stretch of mansions in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was known as Millionaire's Row. Most of the biggest houses there are gone, and Crown Heights has had a busy history since that time. But if millionaires are scarcer today, the good news is that in much of the neighborhood the comfortable ambience they
title: LIVING IN | CROWN HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; A Melting Pot, With the Heat Turned Off

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: WHEN Jen Rosenbaum told her colleagues that she was determined to find an apartment for just $1,200 to $1,500 a month, they laughed. Clearly, she was on a fool's errand. ''My co-workers said it is not going to happen, you are insane,'' she said. But Miss Rosenbaum was certain she could easily find a great cheap apartment. After all, she had heard
title: THE HUNT; An Optimist Goes After the Near-Impossible

body: DESPITE her husband's reluctance to buy a Manhattan apartment, Lauren Olitski Poster insisted. When she began the hunt for a pied-à-terre in January 2009, a number of listings appeared in her price range, $200,000 or less. ''This was our window to get back into the city as a homeowner,'' she told her husband, Bradley Poster. ''It was now or
title: THE HUNT; A Place to Sleep (and Hang Large Paintings)

body: MARIA BERMAN was hopelessly smitten with the working fireplace in her first New York apartment, a third-floor walk-up in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. ''That fireplace was in use most of the year,'' said Ms. Berman, an architect who lived in the apartment in the early 1990s. ''For three years I had quarter cords of wood delivered to my doorstep.'' But in
title: Charmed Obsolescence

body: IT'S Friday night at Alphabet City Wine Company on Avenue C, and the juice is flowing. Two customers lounge on well-worn black vinyl chairs in what could pass for a graduate-school living room. Four more stand in front of a makeshift bar. Music streams from vintage KLH speakers, and Keith Beavers, one of the owners, is deep into his spiel. ''Forget
title: THE POUR; Good Wines And No Attitude. Yes, It's True.

body: TO walk the streets of Brownsville and East New York, Brooklyn, is to see neighborhoods ravaged by foreclosure, homes boarded up and marshals' notices taped to doors. Yet in the midst of this pain sit several swaths of well-tended homes, about 3,000 in all, each with a driveway and statuary and garden. Not one of their owners has lost a home. Five
title: Old-Fashioned Bulwark In a Tide of Foreclosures

body: AMY BRILL, a writer who lives in Windsor Terrace, survived nine months and six days of pregnancy, then 40 hours of labor. But after a few days of nursing, she was in excruciating pain, crying every time her baby latched on. Ms. Brill's pediatrician wrote out a phone number as if it were a prescription. ''Call this woman,'' he said. ''She's seen
title: The Breast Whisperer
